poem:
**In the Dailies**

Words trade hands  
like echoing coins—  
pages lift on whispers  
of old ink,  
newsprint  
unfolding new skies,  
an afternoon headline  
circles the city,  
a hesitant sun—  
we watch promises  
haggled in margins,  
destined  
for a history  
as fleeting as  
today's weather.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "New York Sun owner begins exclusive talks to take over Telegraph The New York Sun owner, Dovid Efune, has begun exclusive talks to buy the Daily and Sunday Telegraph for £550m, the Guardian understands . Efune, a former editor of the New York-based Jewish publication, the Algemeiner Journal, made the highest bid to buy the newspapers last month and has beaten three rivals to become the proprietor. The exclusivity talks will trigger a six-week process". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
